div.l: And to the hors he goth faire and well
He strepith of the bridel / right anoon̄
And whan the hors was loos he bigynneth to goon̄
Toward the fen̄ / there wilde mares renne
And fortwith we hee / thurgh thikke and thenne
This meller goth agayen̄ / no worde he seyde
But doth his note / and with these clerkes pleyde
Til that her corn was faire and wel ygrounde
And whan the mele is sakked and ybounde
This Iohn goth forth / and fynde his hors away
And gan to crie harow / and weleaway
Oure hors is lost Aleyn̄ / for goddes banes
Stepe on thy feet / come of man al attanes
Allas oure wardeyn̄ / has his palfray lorn
This Aleyn̄ al forgat / bothe mele and corn
Al was out of his mynde / his housbonderie
What whilke way is he goon̄ he gan to crie
The wyf come lepyng in at a ren
She saide allas / youre hors goth to the fen
With wilde mares / as fast as he may go
Vnthank come on his hande / that band hym so
And he that bet sholde have knet the reyne
Allas qduod Iohn Aleyn̄ for cristes peyne
Lay doıı̄un thy swerd / and I wil myn̄ alswa
I is ful swift / god wat as is a ra
By goddes herte / he shal nought scape vs bathe
Why ne hadde thou putte the capel in the lathe
Il hayel by god Aleyn̄ thou is a fonne
Thise sely clerkes / han ful faste yronne
Toward the fen / bothe Aleyn and eke Iohn
And whan the Meller saugh that they were goon̄
He half a busshel of here mele hath take
And bid his wyf gon knede it in a cake
And seide I trowe / these Clerkes were aferd
Ȝit can a meller make a clerkes berd
For al here art / ȝe lat hem goon here weye
Lo where they goon̄ / ȝe lat the children pleye
They gete hym nouȝt so lightly by my croıı̄u
